description: Media and communications industries like advertising; film, television; music; radio; and publishing play an integral role in the contemporary information revolution. Around the world, these industries are are perceived to be in crisis. The introduction of new communication technologies has facilitated massive changes in traditional modes of production, distribution, and consumption. Bloggers with a laptop are challenging the hegemony of established newspaper organizations. Online music delivery mechanisms like ITunes are replacing brick and mortar music stores. Using a case study method, this class will explore the structure and dynamics of different cultural industries. We will examine the perceptions about and the realities behind how these industries operate, the challenges they face, and their implications for society. Course readings and class discussion will cover such issues as media ownership, the political economy of media, remix culture, and intellectual property. We will also examine specific case studies such as: Rupert Murdoch's global media empire NewsCorp, the Ugly Betty franchise, and the current challenges challenges facing the New York Times.
